var_drug_ann.Notes: In 68 Colombian pediatric ALL patients on BFM ALLIC 2009 maintenance, 4/68 were rs116855232 C/T heterozygotes; no statistically significant association was identified between NUDT15 rs116855232 and myelotoxicity, liver toxicity, febrile neutropenia, relapse, death, or 6-MP dose reduction/interruption (Table 4, p-values not significant). Two of the four heterozygous patients required a decrease in 6-MP during follow-up, but overall association tests were non-significant.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype C/T is not associated with increased toxicity outcomes of 6-mercaptopurine in children with Disease:Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia as compared to genotype C/C.
Citations: "Seventy pediatric patients were included in the study. No statistically significant association was identified between the genetic variants and the outcomes of interest."

study_parameters.Characteristics: Colombian pediatric ALL patients in maintenance therapy (BFM ALLIC 2009) genotyped for NUDT15 rs116855232; overall genotype distribution
Colombian pediatric ALL patients in maintenance therapy (BFM ALLIC 2009) genotyped for NUDT15 rs116855232; overall genotype distribution
Colombian pediatric ALL patients in maintenance therapy (BFM ALLIC 2009) genotyped for NUDT15 rs116855232; allele frequency comparison with Latin American ALFA data
Colombian pediatric ALL patients in maintenance therapy (BFM ALLIC 2009) genotyped for NUDT15 rs116855232; allele frequency comparison with Latin American ALFA data

summary:
Study question and design:
This single-center, longitudinal observational study evaluated whether functional variants in TPMT and NUDT15 predict thiopurine-related toxicity in Colombian children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) receiving 6‑mercaptopurine (6‑MP) during BFM ALLIC 2009 maintenance therapy in 2017.

Population and methods:
• 70 pediatric ALL patients (1–18 years) in maintenance were enrolled; 68 had DNA of sufficient quality for genotyping.
• Exclusions: age <1 year and Down syndrome.
• SNPs tested by TaqMan allelic discrimination real-time PCR:
  – NUDT15 rs116855232 (c.415C>T)
  – TPMT rs1800462 (*2), rs1800460 (*3B component), rs1142345 (*3C component)
• Outcomes over the first 6 months of maintenance:
  – Myelotoxicity (neutropenia), liver toxicity (ALT/AST, bilirubin)
  – 6‑MP dose reduction or interruption
  – Exploratory: febrile neutropenia, relapse, death.

Key clinical characteristics:
• Median age at start of maintenance: 6 years.
• B‑lineage ALL: 92.9%; T‑ALL: 7.1%.
• Risk groups: standard 10%, intermediate 48.6%, high 41.4%.
• During 6‑month follow‑up:
  – Myelotoxicity: 25%
  – Liver toxicity: 27%
  – 6‑MP dose reduction: 32.9%
  – 6‑MP interruption: 28.6%
  – Febrile neutropenia: 11.4%
  – Relapse: 15.7%; Death: 2.9%.

Genotype frequencies:
• NUDT15 rs116855232:
  – T (risk) allele frequency: 0.03 (4/136 alleles)
  – Genotypes: CC 94% (64/68), CT 6% (4/68), TT 0%; all in HWE.
• Individual TPMT SNPs:
  – rs1800462 (*2): 4 heterozygotes
  – rs1800460 (part of *3A/*3B): 6 heterozygotes
  – rs1142345 (part of *3A/*3C): 4 heterozygotes (typed in 42 patients)
• TPMT star allele typing (42 fully genotyped):
  – Haplotypes: *1: 78, *2: 2, *3A: 4
  – Diplotypes: *1/*1 (36), *1/*2 (2), *1/*3A (4)
  – No homozygous deficient TPMT genotypes detected.
• Observed allele frequencies were similar to ALFA (dbSNP) Latin American reference data, but NUDT15 risk allele frequency was lower than typically reported in East Asian cohorts.

Association with toxicity and treatment modification:
• No statistically significant associations were found between:
  – NUDT15 rs116855232 genotype and any of the primary toxicity outcomes (myelotoxicity, liver toxicity, 6‑MP reduction, 6‑MP interruption) or exploratory outcomes (febrile neutropenia, relapse, death).
  – Any individual TPMT SNP (rs1800462, rs1800460, rs1142345) and these outcomes.
  – TPMT diplotypes (*1/*1 vs *1/*2 or *1/*3A) and outcomes.
• Descriptively:
  – 2 of 4 NUDT15 CT patients required 6‑MP dose reduction.
  – For TPMT rs1800462, 2 of 4 heterozygotes developed febrile neutropenia and required 6‑MP interruption.
  – For TPMT rs1800460, 3 of 6 heterozygotes required dose reduction; 2 of these also carried rs1142345 variants.
• Longitudinal lab parameters (WBC, neutrophils, aminotransferases, bilirubin) showed no significant genotype-based differences.

Interpretation and context:
• This is the first Colombian pediatric ALL pharmacogenomic study assessing both TPMT and NUDT15.
• The NUDT15 risk allele frequency (0.03) was lower than in East Asian cohorts but within the range of admixed Latin American populations, likely reflecting substantial European (50–60%) ancestry in this Colombian Andean cohort.
• TPMT *2 and *3A frequencies were modestly higher than a previous Colombian report but in the range described for Latin American populations; only intermediate-activity genotypes (*1/*2, *1/*3A) were observed, with no poor-metabolizer diplotypes.
• The lack of statistically significant genotype–toxicity associations is plausibly explained by:
  – Small sample size (68 genotyped patients, very few variant carriers), which limits power.
  – Absence of TPMT or NUDT15 poor metabolizers (no homozygous risk genotypes).
  – Possible differences in ancestry structure and environmental or treatment factors relative to the populations in which strong associations have been reported.

Implications for pharmacogenomics and clinical practice:
• In this real-world Colombian pediatric ALL cohort, TPMT and NUDT15 variants as tested (major CPIC-relevant alleles) did not predict 6‑MP toxicity or dose adjustments during the first 6 months of BFM ALLIC 2009 maintenance.
• Given the low frequency of high-risk genotypes, routine testing may yield few actionable findings in this setting unless done in larger or pooled cohorts.
• Nonetheless, given robust evidence from other populations and current CPIC guidelines, TPMT/NUDT15 genotyping remains biologically and clinically relevant; this study emphasizes that effect sizes and allele frequencies may vary by ancestry, reinforcing the need for local data.

Authors’ conclusions and recommendations:
• Allele frequencies of TPMT and NUDT15 in this Colombian cohort differ somewhat from previously described Latin American estimates, but fall within a broadly similar range.
• No statistically significant associations were identified between the polymorphisms studied and thiopurine-related toxicity or treatment modifications.
• Larger, ideally multicenter, studies in Colombia and Latin America are needed to:
  – Achieve adequate power to detect genotype–toxicity relationships.
  – Investigate additional variants in TPMT, NUDT15 and other thiopurine pathway genes.
  – Explore the role of detailed genetic ancestry in modifying pharmacogenomic effects.
• The authors highlight the need to search for “autochthonous biomarkers” tailored to admixed Latin American populations to better predict thiopurine toxicity in pediatric oncology and potentially in other thiopurine-treated pediatric diseases (e.g., IBD, JIA).
title: Susceptibility to thiopurine toxicity by TPMT and NUDT15 variants in Colombian children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia

[Table 4] summarizes the results of the bivariate analyzes in which the correlation between the genetic variants of the SNPs of interest in NUDT15 and TPMT and the side effects of interest. No association was found between the outcomes of interest and the genetic variant of NUDT15 or any TPMT polymorphisms evaluated individually.

In the case of rs1800460, of the six heterozygous patients, three required a dosage decrease, and two were also heterozygous for rs1142345. Additionally, differences in the median for the lab values taken in the first 6 months of maintenance treatment were evaluated: aminotransferases, total bilirubin, leukocytes, and differential cell counts; based on genetic variants, no statistically significant differences were found ([Supplementary table 2S]).
